body: @gnethercutt I can merge this if you agree to our CLA and clean it up.
Actually, let me do some larger scale integration test real quick.
At the very minimum, I can start up a broker, coordinator, and historical and have them be able to see each other.

I got the email notifications of changes here, haven't had a chance to look
at the code changes yet, was going to do that but wanted to understand why
the code is changing in the first place.  I don't see any explanation of
what was wrong and/or what is being fixed by switching to a concurrent
queue.

This is actually somewhat typical of commits and PRs against the project to
date.  It's quite difficult to follow what is happening and why for people
external.  Can I request that PRs either refer to an issue or include some
description of the high-level reasoning for what is being changed?

On Tuesday, November 25, 2014, Charles Allen notifications@github.com
wrote:

> - Change StupidPool to use a concurrent queue
> - Modify OffheapBufferPool to pull from an expanding memory mapped file
> 
> ---
> 
> You can merge this Pull Request by running
> 
>   git pull https://github.com/metamx/druid offheapFileMappedBufferPool
> 
> Or view, comment on, or merge it at:
> 
>   https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/910
> Commit Summary
> - Modify StupidPool usage
> 
> File Changes
> - _M_ common/src/main/java/io/druid/collections/StupidPool.java
>   https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/910/files#diff-0 (25)
> - _M_ server/src/main/java/io/druid/offheap/OffheapBufferPool.java
>   https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/910/files#diff-1 (106)
> 
> Patch Links:
> - https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/910.patch
> - https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/910.diff
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/910.

@cheddar 
Basic problem: Group By queries are having issues with running out of memory when there are a loooot of items grouped.

I went in and modified some StupidPool stuff to make it use actual memory mapped files instead of direct memory, thus hopefully allowing for softer problems related to very-large-memory-using group by queries.

Modifying the mechanism to use a concurrent queue is simply part of my crusade to use java internals instead of customized operations on items. Why synchronize around a linked list when there's already a concurrent linked list inherent to java?
It should be noted this is a proposal and not necessarily the best solution to the issue at hand (large memory utilization of some group by queries).

Understood on the group by thing.  I guess switching to memory mapped files
gets around the arbitrary limit that the JVM places on direct memory?

Regarding Java internals, I agree with the sentiment and actually intended
to do that when writing the code.  That said, there are sometimes cases
where I updated state alongside an underlying collection anyway and
doubling the synchronization overhead doesn't actually buy you anything.  I
haven't looked at the changes yet to know if that is the case here or not,
but please make doubly sure that the changes you make don't introduce new
behaviors :).

On Monday, December 1, 2014, Charles Allen notifications@github.com wrote:

> It should be noted this is a proposal and not necessarily the best
> solution to the issue at hand (large memory utilization of some group by
> queries).
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/910#issuecomment-65154781.
Temporarily closing because it doesn't persist zookeeper stuff correctly
@zhaown, try the intellij formatting file, which is what we use.

Before I can merge the pull request, we need you to
agree to our CLA. In the repo there is an individual CLA and a corporate
CLA. If you are working on your own behalf and agree to the CLA, responding
here with a comment of "I agree to the terms of the Druid Individual CLA as
it exists in the current master branch" is sufficient. If you are working on
behalf of a company, can you have your company fill out the corporate CLA
and submit it to us? Thanks for the contrib!
I meant to say, I can merge this and help clean it up :P

Merged from master -- I don't mind some cleaning. And I'll send along a signed CLA.

I can follow up with the Guice bindings contributed by @drcrallen (https://github.com/metamx/druid/commit/633426724f80072f6a6cb6b3781606d422336c06) but I haven't been able to test them in our cluster yet.

@xvrl  / @fjy : Found the cause of the error. There was a weird race condition whereby the sequenced input stream was being closed before all the data had actually been finished in the client http handler. As such, adding a zero-length byte array as an "input stream" allows the SequenceInputStream close() method to cleanly do its thing regardless of when it was called in the race condition.
Temporarily closing to address comments.
Out of curiosity, is there anything in 2.4.4 needed?

Can you have add a unit test which uses both min and max times from the JodaUtils?

I only see MAX used in any unit tests.

Predominantly bug fixes and performance improvements, notably fixes a performance regression in the Scala module, which downstream users depend on.

There are also a few notable features we could benefit from, namely:
- new Guice module https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-module-guice
- support for ByteBuffers
- better Joda support, which means we might be able to use the built-in module instead of our own DateTime (e.g. timezone related stuff)
Unit tests indirectly use MIN_INSTANT through some of the other classes, e.g. IndexMerger is used by GroupByQueryRunnerTest. If I switch MIN_INSTANT to Long.MIN_VALUE, lots of tests break.
Hi @xvrl, do you have numbers on how much this improves things?

From the [docs](http://fasterxml.github.io/jackson-dataformat-smile/javadoc/2.0.6/com/fasterxml/jackson/dataformat/smile/SmileGenerator.Feature.html#ENCODE_BINARY_AS_7BIT):

```
but since overhead for binary data (14% size expansion, processing overhead) is non-negligible, it is not enabled by default
```

odd, I'm getting


Classpath fail for some reason. This is using the tar.gz file built automatically
I had lz4-1.2.0.jar on the classpath as well as 1.3.0... for some reason it didn't pick up the 1.3.0 properly.

The code says it is enabled by default. The documentation contradicts itself, further down it says default is true. I trust the code more :)

@fjy , sorry for the slowly response, I'd looked the CLA once I was informed, and asked reviewed by my team leader who granted me to sign it on behalf of my own just now, then a can confirm that: "I agree to the terms of the Druid Individual CLA as it exists in the current master branch". 
Glad to contribute to this brilliant project. :)
Thanks @estliberitas !

@fjy 

One irrelevant question: I'm moving to Intellij IDEA after using Eclipse for about 4 years, w/ lots of surprise I just found that you can't step-on single thread while debuging with IDEA(WTF?!), I cant belive this until found this issue still open: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-43728...

I think IDEA is good at editoring, organizing projects, and should be good at debuging web-based programes, but how do you guys debuging multi-threaded programes like druids with IDEA?

Thanks.

Hi Zhaown, can you post this on the developers forum please
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/druid-development ? it's better at
searching than commit chatter, and this is one of the most relevant things
I've ever seen come from the community.

@metacret : Can you give more detail on your expected behavior when querying an overlord that is not the leader?
@drcrallen I asked @metacret to file this as /status should not redirect on the coordinator and overlord.
@fjy : Rgr

I'm fixing this already

On Wed, Dec 10, 2014 at 11:21 AM, Charles Allen notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @fjy https://github.com/fjy : Rgr
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/metamx/druid/issues/953#issuecomment-66507365.

Our system heathcheck module is checking for each individual instance's health status using registered health check URL as the following image I attached. Asgard itself can follow redirection and report it's healthy but healthcheck backend switched their behavior not to follow redirection.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1091109/5382587/efb308b6-805f-11e4-8571-30e99b72d6b3.png)
Can this be named something more descriptive like DataSourceIntervalQuery or something?

I think IngestMetadataQuery is a good level to have the query at, because we may add other kinds of ingest metadata later and it's going to be convenient for users to be able to send a query listing the things they want to know and then get a report back.

The simple answer for 'why no min date' is that there is not currently a use case for it :)

It could be interesting though so I think it's reasonable to add if it's easy. Then you could use this query as an alternative to timeBoundary if you care more about ingested timestamps than stored timestamps.
@gianm : Since everything else in druid revolves around Intervals, I was kind of expecting this to return an Interval result instead of an Instant
@gianm : Good point on the future compatibility. In that case, could it just be part of the already existing metadata query?

The way I was thinking of it is that SegmentMetadataQuery returns per-segment information about storage related things, and IngestMetadataQuery returns per-datasource information about ingestion related things. I'm pretty open to other ways of structuring things though.
Prior implementation had /status go through redirect filter, this one does not, confirmed
fixed in https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/954
@gianm : works for me, can it be renamed to DatasourceMetadataQuery instead then?

When I first saw the pull request I expected the query to actually A) ingest something and B) modify the metadata somehow. It does neither, which is why I'm trying to find a good name that fits what it really does.

Can we backport to 0.6.x?

Hi @xvrl : is there a way you can get a JUnit test that shows the error?
Is there anything that having both causes issues for?
Have you tried benchmarking gzip vs uncompressed? I've seen multiple times where gzip over a fast connection actually DECREASES throughput.
Please update https://github.com/metamx/druid/blob/ingestmetadata-query/docs/content/Querying.md with this query type.

@fjy : How can this be added to the "significant changes" for 0.7?

I don't think that anyone is using it, but it would suck if someone was and it was removed but not documented.
@xvrl : any other comments?
do we have any numbers on resource contention and how this will help with that problem?
@drcrallen agree, afaik no one uses this endpoint and we've never even told people about it, nor is it documented, but it should be added to the release notes
I don't think this has all the changes we made together
I would hate to have this "fixed" and have our queries take longer because of it.

I'm not sure there's a good way to unit test that something is using the right service name, but integration tests will certainly catch this. Instead I marked the method protected and added some docs as to why it has no reason to be used outside of the curator-specific service discovery code.

On the broker endpoint, I believe we should leave it up to the client to decide whether to accept gzip encoding or not. It helps a lot when querying through a browser or using one of the client libraries, as those are rarely on the same high-bandwidth network.

Between nodes, it will depend a lot on available CPU and bandwidth. Given that we don't use plain JSON anymore, Smile by itself may be enough for very high bandwidth networks, in which case we could make it configurable.

@fjy : I'm testing it this morning, and this particular deadlock is not showing up.

I am, however, seeing other issues related to the ServerInventoryView. It is not clear that this is a new problem compared to 0.6.x though.

Here's the symptom:

| Quartile | Latency (ms) |
| --- | --- |
| min | 828 |
| 25% | 966.25 |
| 50% | 1032 |
| 75% | 1165 |
| max | 93287 |

As you can see, in general things look pretty good, but every once in a while the server inventory view is doing a lot of child_updated, and a query can take a very long time during this period. This time on the broker is spent waiting for the historical to respond as far as I can tell.

I wonder if our newly added logs are affecting things...

Adding full log4j2 conversion shortly

Now has log4j2.xml and includes the slf4j impl in the common package.

NOTE!!!
Anyone using a custom log4j.xml will need to upgrade when/if this gets merged.

```
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.lmax</groupId>
            <artifactId>disruptor</artifactId>
        </dependency>
```

is declared `optional` in `log4j-core`, so we must include it here
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
